member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient
member.summary: Instances of this class can interact with an IMAP server.

remarks.para: An instance may connect many times, possibly to different IMAP servers, but can only have one active connection at a time.
To connect to an IMAP server use the method. Before calling set the and properties at a minimum. Also consider setting the property.
Note that the class implements , so you should dispose instances when you are finished with them.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.NetworkWriteConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the network-write batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can terminate the instance. Can only be set while .
member.remarks: Limits the size of the buffer used when sending data to the server. Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.summary: Gets and sets the instance idle configuration. May be .

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.AppendStreamReadConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the default append-stream-read batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can terminate the instance.
member.remarks: Limits the size of the buffer when reading from the client-side stream (e.g. when reading an attachment from local disk). Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.FetchCacheItemsConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the fetch-cache-items batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
member.remarks: Limits the number of messages per batch when requesting cache-items from the server. Measured in number of messages. The default value is min=1 message, max=1000 messages, maxtime=10s, initial=1 message.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.FetchBodyReadConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the fetch-body-read batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
member.remarks: Limits the size of the section parts when requesting body sections from the server. Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.FetchBodyWriteConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the fetch-body-write batch-size configuration. You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
member.remarks: Limits the size of the buffer when writing to the client-side stream (e.g. when writing to the local disk). Measured in bytes. The default value is min=1000b, max=1000000b, maxtime=10s, initial=1000b.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cIMAPClient.Connect
member.summary: Connects to the using the . Can only be called when the instance . Will throw if an authenticated IMAP connection cannot be established.

remarks.para: TLS is established if possible before authentication is attempted. TLS will be established immediately upon TCP connect if the specifies , otherwise the library will use the IMAP STARTTLS command if both the server and client support it (see and ).

During the authentication part of connecting the will be set (most likely more than once). The value is used to determine what capabilities offered by the server are actually used by the client. It is possible that the will be set during authentication: this indicates that the connected server suggests that we disconnect and try a different server. If authentication is successful then the will be set.

After authentication, depending on what the allow;
is enabled (see , ); this sets the property.
ID (RFC 2971) information is exchanged with the server; this sends the (or ) and sets the property.
Namespace (RFC 2342) information is retrieved from the server; this sets the property.
A special syntax IMAP LIST command is used to discover the hierarchy delimiter and one personal namespace may be generated using it (setting the property).

Normally only one of Namespace and LIST are used during connect, but under some strange circumstances both may be required. (The specific case is when the personal namespaces retrieved from the server do not contain the INBOX.) Once the are known the property is set.
At the end of a successful connect the will be , at the end of a failed connect the will be and this method will throw.

Some of the exceptions that might be thrown and why;
The server actively rejected the connection.
The client was able to try credentials from , but they didn't work. If the server explicitly rejected the credentials using one of the , or codes, then the will contain the details (otherwise the will be ).
The client was not able to try any credentials from . If the TLS state was to blame for this then will be set to .
While connecting the server either refused to connect or refused to authenticate and suggested that we try a different server instead (see and the contained ).

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary
member.summary: Contains a summary of feeback on a store operation.

remarks.para: Each message counts towards ONE of;
Generally + is the number of definite non-updates.
Generally > 0 indicates that a may be worth trying to get any pending updates from the server (which should convert all the notreflects to expunged or reflects).
Note that after a you should get the summary again using or
> 0 indicates that a blind store was done so there isn't enough information to say if the store happened or not.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.UpdatedCount
member.summary: The count where an IMAP FETCH for the message was received during the command execution and the message wasn't mentioned in the RFC 7162 MODIFIED response (=> the message was _likely_ to have been updated by the store).

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.WasNotUnchangedSinceCount
member.summary: The count where the message was mentioned in the RFC 7162 MODIFIED response (=> _NOT_ updated by the store).

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.ExpungedCount
member.summary: The count where the message cache indicates that the message is expunged.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.UnknownCount
member.summary: The count where the internal message cache item isn't known or the internal message cache item does not contain the flags.

member.summary: The count where the flags in the internal message cache reflect the store operation.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.NotReflectsOperationCount
member.summary: The count where the flags in the internal message cache do not reflect the store operation.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox
member.summary: Provides an API that allows interaction with an IMAP mailbox.

remarks.para: Instances are only valid whilst the containing remains connected. Reconnecting the client will not bring mailbox instances back to life.

To interact with messages in a mailbox, IMAP requires that the mailbox be selected - use the method of this class to select the mailbox associated with the instance. Each IMAP connection (and hence each instance) can have at most one selected mailbox selecting a mailbox automatically un-selects the previously selected mailbox. An instance of this class may be selected and un-selected many times in its lifetime. Each time an instance is selected a new select session is started. instances are valid only within a 'select session'.

member.summary: The client that this instance was created by.

member.remarks: If is not , events are invoked on the specified . If an exception is raised in an event handler the event is raised, but otherwise the exception is ignored.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.RecentCount

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.UIDNext
member.summary: Gets the predicted next UID for the mailbox. May be or zero. This property always has a value when the mailbox is selected, but it may not be up-to-date.

remarks.para: indicates that is not being requested (see ) or that the value was not sent when requested.
When the mailbox is selected, zero indicates that the value is unknown.
While the mailbox is selected the value of this property may not be up-to-date: see the value of for the potential inaccuracy in this property value.
IMAP does not mandate that the server keep the client updated with this value while a mailbox is selected but it also disallows retrieving the value for a mailbox while the mailbox is selected.
While the mailbox is selected the library internally maintains the value of this property by monitoring IMAP FETCH responses from the server, but these responses have to be explicitly requested.
If it is important to you that the value of this property be accurate when the mailbox is selected then you must fetch the for new messages as they arrive.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.UIDNextUnknownCount
member.summary: Indicates how inaccurate the is.
member.remarks: This is the count of messages that have arrived since the mailbox was selected for which the library has not seen the value of the UID.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.UIDValidity
member.summary: Gets the UIDValidity of the mailbox. May be or zero. This property always has a value when the mailbox is selected.
member.remarks: indicates that the mailbox does not support UIDs or that the is not being requested (see ) or that the value was not sent when requested. Zero indicates that the server does not support UIDs.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.UnseenCount
member.summary: Gets the number of unseen messages in the mailbox. May be . This property always has a value when the mailbox is selected, but it may not be up-to-date.

remarks.para: indicates that is not being requested (see ) or that the value was not sent when requested.
While the mailbox is selected the value of this property may not be up-to-date: see the value of for the potential inaccuracy in this property value.
IMAP does not provide a mechanism for getting this value while a mailbox is selected.

While the mailbox is selected the library internally maintains the value of this property by monitoring IMAP FETCH responses from the server, but the property value has to be explicitly initialised and the FETCH responses have to be explicitly requested.
If it is important to you that the value of this property be accurate when the mailbox is selected then you must initialise the value by using and also fetch the for new messages as they arrive.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.UnseenUnknownCount
member.summary: Indicates how inaccurate the is.
member.remarks: This is the number of messages for which the library is unsure of the value of the flag.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMailbox.HighestModSeq
member.summary: Gets the modification sequence number for the mailbox (see RFC 7162). May be or zero. When the mailbox is selected this property will always have a value.

remarks.para: indicates that is not being requested (see ) or that the value was not sent when requested.
Zero indicates that cannot be used or the mailbox associated with this instance does not support modification sequence numbers.

member.summary: Stores flags for a message. The mailbox must be selected.

The modseq to use in the UNCHANGEDSINCE clause of a conditional store (see RFC 7162). Can only be specified if is not zero. If the message has been modified since the specified modseq the server should fail the store.

member.remarks: Instances are only valid whilst the containing mailbox remains selected. Re-selecting a mailbox will not bring the message instances back to life. Instances are only valid whilst the containing mailbox has the same UIDValidity.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.Attachments
member.summary: Gets the list of message attachments. The list may be empty.
member.remarks: The library defines an attachment as a message part with a disposition of attachment. If there are alternate versions of an attachment only one of the alternates is included in the list (the first one). If the internal message cache does not contain the of the message, it will be fetched from the server.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.PlainTextSizeInBytes
member.summary: Gets the size in bytes of the plain text parts of the message. May be zero.
member.remarks: The library defines plain text parts as parts with a MIME type of text/plain and without a disposition of 'attachment'. If there are alternate versions of a part only one of the alternates is used in calculating the size (the first one). If the internal message cache does not contain the of the message, it will be fetched from the server.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.References
member.summary: Gets the normalised message-ids from the references header field. May be .
member.remarks: Normalised message-ids have the delimiters, quoting, comments and white space removed. May be if there is no references header field or if the references header field can not be parsed by the library. If the internal message cache does not contain the header field of the message, it will be fetched from the server.

member.name: P:work.bacome.imapclient.cMessage.Importance
member.summary: Gets the importance value from the importance header field. May be .
member.remarks: May be if there is no importance header field or if the importance header field can not be parsed by the library. If the internal message cache does not contain the header field of the message, it will be fetched from the server.

member.name: T:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration
member.summary: Contains parameters that control what a instance does while idle.

remarks.para: Idling refers to the process of inviting the server to send unprompted (unprompted by external code) updates to the client with the aim of keeping the client in synch with the server.
A instance can only idle while it .
Idling starts after the configured length of quiet time on the underlying IMAP protocol connection has passed (see ).

If is in use then the RFC 2177 IDLE command is used. The IDLE command has to be restarted periodically to avoid the connection being closed due to inactivity - RFC 2177 recommends at least once every 29 minutes (see ).
If is not in use then the library drops back to a periodic poll of the server using IMAP CHECK and/ or NOOP (see ).

The default values are;
2s
20 minutes
60s

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.StartDelay
member.summary: The length of the quiet time that must pass before idling starts, in milliseconds.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.IdleRestartInterval
member.summary: The interval between RFC 2177 IDLE commands, in milliseconds.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.PollInterval
member.summary: The interval between polling commands, in milliseconds.

member.name: M:work.bacome.imapclient.cIdleConfiguration.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialises a new instance.
member.param: The length of the quiet time that must pass before idling starts, in milliseconds.
The interval between RFC 2177 IDLE commands, in milliseconds.
The interval between polling commands, in milliseconds.

member.summary: Returns a string that represents the configuration.

member.name: T:work.bacome.async.cExclusiveAccess
member.summary: Instances provide a mechanism to control exclusive access using token objects and block objects.

remarks.para: The granting of exclusive access is done by issuing a token object. To release the exclusive access the token object must be disposed.
The issuing of token objects may be blocked by the previous issue of block objects. Several block objects can be on issue at the same time. Blocks are released by disposing the block objects.
Block objects will not be issued while a token object is issued. Token objects will not be issued while block objects are issued (nor while a token object is issued).
Instance sequence numbers (specified in the constructor) can be used by external code to ensure that the program's locks are being taken in a consistent order (to avoid deadlocks).
Each instance of this class is allocated a unique instance number internally that is used in messages to aid debugging.
Note that this class implements , so you should dispose instances when you are finished with them.

member.name: T:work.bacome.trace.cTrace
member.summary: Instances wrap a and provide services to write trace messages with indenting and context information.

remarks.para: The concept is that trace messages are written in a context. The context starts with independent root-contexts. Sub-contexts can be established within root-contexts and within other sub-contexts.
If a new sub-context is created for each call then call stack information can be built and included in the trace.

The writing of context trace messages can be delayed until a non-context trace message is written, or context trace messages can be written as the contexts are created. (Note however that if the writing is delayed then the generation of the context trace messages is also delayed. If there are mutable objects to be included in the context trace message then this may lead to misleading context trace messages. It is done like this for efficiency reasons.)

Tracing can be disabled. When tracing is disabled contexts are not created and trace messages are not emitted, so most of the tracing overhead is eliminated. Tracing is disabled under the following circumstances;
The assembly is compiled without the "TRACE" conditional attribute.
There aren't any listeners attached to the when the instance is created.
The isn't configured to emit critical messages when the instance is created.
The context is used.
Root-contexts have a name and a number. The name is programmer assigned, the number is internally assigned and is unique.
Trace messages are indented by a number of spaces that equals the context stack depth.

Trace messages are written in a tab delimited form, the tab delimited columns contain;
The defined data.
The date and time that the message was written.
The name and number of the root-context associated with the trace message.
The thread number on which the trace message was written.
The space indented trace message.
